Web search - Kittyhawk III specifications (P-40K: max speed 362 mph at 15,000 ft, range 350 miles with bomb load, ferry range 1,600 miles; P-40M: max speed 334 mph, max range 850 miles, armament 6× 12.7mm machine guns + 910kg bombs)
Web search - 239 Wing organization (formed 1 March 1942 with Nos. 3, 112, 250 Squadrons; escorted Boston bombers; ground attack missions; El Alamein participation October-November 1942)
metadata.notes: No. 250 Squadron (Sudan) RAF converted to Kittyhawks February-April 1942, returning to Western Desert in time for Battle of Gazala (May-June 1942). Squadron operated Kittyhawk I and II through October 1942, transitioning to Kittyhawk III from October 1942 onward. Squadron Leader Mike Judd commanded during two periods in 1942: April 5-July 23 and early September-November 23. Aircraft carried squadron codes 'LD-?' with red arrow marking over exhaust stubs. Mike Judd flew AK919 LD-B (P-40E Kittyhawk I), scoring 4 victories with the squadron including a Ju-87 destroyed on 8 July 1942. Squadron moved frequently during Q4: LG.106 (October), multiple forward landing grounds (November), Martuba 4 (Nov-Dec), Belandah 1 (December). Assigned to No. 239 Wing on 27 October 1942 alongside 3 Squadron RAAF and 112 Squadron RAF. Primary mission: fighter-bomber operations supporting 8th Army during El Alamein and subsequent pursuit across Cyrenaica. Canadian pilot F/Lt Gordie Troke flew FR120 LD-E (Kittyhawk III) December 1942-February 1943, scoring 3 kills and 2 shared. Squadron transitioned fully to fighter-bomber role by Q4 1942, carrying 250 lb and 500 lb GP bombs for ground attack while maintaining air combat capability.
metadata.witw_validation: WITW _airgroup.csv file not located. Further investigation needed for game database cross-reference.

tier_1_sources_used: RAF fighter squadron establishment standards (16 aircraft for Desert Air Force squadrons)
Kittyhawk technical specifications from multiple corroborated sources
239 Wing organizational structure and mission profile
tier_2_sources_used: History of War - No. 250 Squadron RAF (base locations, aircraft variants, organizational assignment timeline)
Asisbiz.com - 250 Squadron RAF aircraft profiles (specific serials: AK919, FR120, FR241, FR243 with LD squadron codes; red arrow marking; pilot assignments)
Aces of WW2 - Mike Judd biographical data (command dates, kill totals, decorations)
source_validation.corroboration_notes: Aircraft variants confirmed via Tier 2 (History of War): Curtiss Kittyhawk I and II April-October 1942, Curtiss Kittyhawk III October 1942-January 1944. Specific aircraft serials confirmed via Tier 2 (Asisbiz): AK919 LD-B (Judd's mount, P-40E), FR120 LD-E (Troke, P-40K), FR241 LD-R (P-40K at LG 91 during Operation LIGHTFOOT), FR243 LD-I (P-40K, 2 MC.202 kills 4 and 7 November 1942 credited to F/Lt Neil Gillespie Russell). Squadron codes 'LD-?' with red arrow marking over exhaust stubs confirmed via Asisbiz. Mike Judd command periods confirmed via Tier 2 (Aces of WW2): April 5-July 23, 1942 and early September-November 23, 1942; 4 kills with 250 Squadron, 5 total by end of war. Base locations confirmed via Tier 2 (History of War): LG.106 (October), LG.106/LG.101/LG.76/Gambut 1/Gambut 2 (November), Martuba 4 (November-December), Belandah 1 (December). Organizational assignment confirmed: No.239 Wing, No.211 Group, A.H.Q. Western Desert, Middle East Command on 27 October 1942. Squadron establishment (16 aircraft) based on RAF Desert Air Force standards. P-40K and P-40M technical specifications from multiple web sources: max speed 334-362 mph, range 350-850 miles depending on load, armament 6× 12.7mm machine guns + up to 910kg bombs. 239 Wing composition and mission profile confirmed: formed 1 March 1942 with Australian and RAF squadrons (3, 112, 250), escorted Boston bombers, conducted ground attack missions, participated in El Alamein offensive.
